reviewText:
Short levels and many variations of play and enemies make this fast, often frantic and awesome. Two buttons is all it has, but two buttons is all you need to lay waste with style!

To break it down:
The action can change up from slowly trundling enemies at you one at a time from either the left or right side of the screen. Once they get close enough, you click either the left mouse button or the right mouse button (or relevant button you are using) to attack the left or right side of your character respectively. Basic enemies go down with one hit, the animation of which seems to vary depending on the combat style used in the stage and the current combo your character is in. Tougher enemies are not simply enemies that take more hits, but also ones that dodge after the first hit, moving to the other side of your character, or the enemies that fight you one-on-one in a cool fast-paced fight after which the  other enemies come at you again.
Weapons drop pretty frequently and are often literally thrown at your character, forcing you to either become a pin cusion or deflect those blades like a badass as they get near. Getting hold of a weapon makes your character either begin pummelling enemies with it until it breaks, or throw it at your enemies for ranged attacks.
Completing certain stages unlocks powerups, of which you can initially slot three at a time. These give you advantages such as three shots with dropped ranged weapons instead of one, extended melee range or even a freezing blast that turns enemies into even more decor to destroy.

Pros:
Fast-paced  - Keeps things intense and fun. There's nothing quite like pulling off an epic combo and finishing with style!

Easy to learn, difficult to master - You seriously cannot go wrong with two buttons. But you also cannot simply button mash, as you will die pretty fast if you do so. Easy to pick up and play.

Short, varied levels (and lots of them!) - Short levels means you can pick up and play this anytime, you never feel like you are doing the same things over and over and the variation of the levels is interesting enough to keep things fresh throughout.

Stick men - Stick man fighting is an old concept, but a fun one!

Cons:
Art style - I'd actually say the art style is great, but sometimes it feels a little unpolished with the animations, which, for such a simple yet in-depth game, is a real shame but does nothing to detract from the fun.

One more level! - Could possibly loose more time to this than expected... the levels are short so one more level!" doesn't seem as dangerous! xD

Adapting - Button mashers aside

reviewText:
Quick reflexes and enemy prioritization are the skills that you will need in OFDP. Don't let the fast paced action fool you into thinking this is some mash to win affair, mashing will only get you killed quicker. This game reminded me a lot of the combat system in the Batman Arkham series, albeit simplified and striped down to its core then applied to a 2 button mouse.
Also I got a little hint of Kung Fu Master (arcade, NES) and that fight scene from Old boy.
The visuals match the simple controls with slo-mo, special effects and a camera that zooms in to 1 on 1 fights with mini bosses adding some flare to the side on 2D view.
The sounds are straight out of those classic kung fu flicks, loads of kiai screaming, hearts ripped out of chests sound like hearts getting ripped out of chests should.

Even though this is a 2 button game, I did find the control scheme slightly awkward at first, after a few rounds of the early story mode levels OFDP's basic and some finer details clicked with me. This is one of those 'in the zone' games, where you know what needs done and you'll do it without thinking.

Special shout-out to 'the ball'. Now one of my favourite power ups from any game.

Overall, a very satisfying title with a huge story mode map and the endless challenge of survival modes. Fun for a quick 10 minute time waster, I've had a lot of entertainment hot seating this game with friends and there is enough content and variation in the gameplay to keep you curious to see what is waiting on the next stage.
Any fans of kung fu should give this one a go, same goes for people who like Divekick or weird little indie games.

reviewText: Who woulda thought that a 2 button game would be good? Unfortunately this one is not good. Its GREAT! Meaning if you press a button too many times, not enough times, or not at all, it is game over man! Then throw in some weapons and it becomes coorindated chaos. I've gotta make this review short so that I can get back to playing but even at $4.99 this game is worth every penny. Passing this one on sale is not a good idea. Why you ask? Otherwise I can not find any reason to not jump on this one.

reviewText:
Simple idea, crazy addictive and fun.

I never paid much attention to this game because I don't care much for brawler games but I picked it up about a month ago in a bundle and decided to try it out.  Four weeks later I have 41 hours clocked in and no sign of that slowing down any time soon.  While it might look like a brawler, it plays more akin to a rhythm-based game on steroids.

This is a casual game at its best.  There is a multitude of levels and a seemingly endless variety of skill combinations to tweak the experience.  You can play a level or two in five minutes or play for an hour or two and wonder where the time went.  Skill combinations that work on easier levels don't work on the more insane levels, and likewise strategies for the more difficult levels are kinda useless on easier levels.  You might find a strategy that works for you for large portions of the game but you will have to alter it later on as things get faster.

When I wake up in the morning and put a pot of coffee on to brew, I'll play a level quick and the game's intense enough that that will wake me up fully before the coffee is even ready.  The response system between clicking the mouse and the action on the screen is perfect and you are only limited by your ability to click the mouse.  I was plateauing fairly early into the grandmaster levels when my gamer son explained to me you can click faster by arching your hand in a claw grip instead of resting your hand flat on the mouse.  It took a little while to acclimate to using the mouse in this way and I still alternate between the two grips, but when the game starts getting insane, the claw grip really does make a world of difference.


Like I said, I'd seen the ads for One Finger Death Punch and never paid any attention to the game.  Skyrim or DayZ or RockBand or Tomb Raider whatnot, that's the sort of stuff I pay attention to.  Didn't care that the game lists at $5, it's just not he sort of game I'd expect to be interested in.  Now that I've played OFDP, the amount of replayability and sheer fun I've had with this game, I could've spent $20-30 on this game and still felt like it was money well spent.

reviewText:
Wow. Such a simple mechanic in this game, but with flawless execution.

If you like intense, fast-paced action with only two actions keys (left and right mouse click), then you will love this game.

The aesthetics are fantastic! The character art may just be stick figures, but the different fighting styles and choreography is absolutely amazing. The gore is pretty good, and it even goes into slow-motion x-ray killcams every now and then (with eyeballs flying toward the screen). While you fight, your opponents will fly into and destroy the environment - for example, an enemy may be thrown into the pillar of a building, causing it to collapse. The music and sounds are great and add to the fast-paced, gameplay.

The controls are extremely simple - simply click the left or right mouse button depending on which direction your opponent is coming from. You have to time your clicks correctly, clicking only when an enemy is within your radius (indicated by gauges to the left and right). Misclicking will result in a miss" against
date: and most likely a counterattack. The learning curve is minimal

reviewText:
The game helps you to speed up and slow down your mind thru a process of counting and reaction. I'm unhappy with the game, because for it to truly help gamers, they need an option where a person can have full range of the entire screen, and click right and left. While the limited range of attack has it's purpose. It limits player who need intensity training. I'm dissatisfied with the game due to 3 reasons. 1st you can't set the speed of attack manually, even at later levels. 2nd you can't set the range of attack. 3rd. A lot of the items impede speed training instead of promoting it, for instance the weapons take 1 click to pick up, and 2nd click to strike, randomly dropped weapons then become a hindrance, and can cause a miss due to user not clicking twice or miss due to clicking twice. Weapon pickup system needs to be perfected especially since they have 0 tolerance for hit or miss. It's also crazy that you can get hit 4 times and miss 0 and get more reward. Missing an opponent is worse than being hit by one and frustrating when playing. No reward for killing `99 ppl just consequence for missing one guy then killing him again with the second click.  The miss system seems to me to be flawed.
'Oh Master Yin punched the air, he loses a point, oh he punched again and killed a man, he gets a point. '
I do realize the sys is in place to prevent spammers, though more distance or double click instead of single click miss allowances are needed. Bare min just allowing a no enemy weapons option would make me happy. Too many random weapon frustrations when playing. I've enjoyed it though it can be more enjoyable with more options. It should be ez for creators to add more fun options if the creators still exist. Either way it‚Äôs a fun cheap game.

reviewText:
Holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, this game. I picked it up on a lark and for the rest of the day, every free moment I had was spent slaughtering stickmen. One Finger Death Punch is a two-button fighting game, pitting your kung fu stick guy against hordes of other stick guys. Playable with mouse or controller, your left button attacks to the left, and your right button attacks to the right. That's it. There's no movement, no jumping, no button combos, just two attacks. The trick is that enemies must be close enough to hit when you push the button, otherwise you whiff and leave yourself momentarily open to get hit. With hundreds of marauding stickmen bearing down with you, some requiring multiple hits or juking on you, that can get frantic real fast.

The beauty of OFDP is how it plays out your simple button presses. Each attack is animated in a different way, forming a ballet of murderous moves when the enemies get dense. There are tons of special attacks that come up as the right circumstances are met, such as power smashing foes through walls, pinning them with knives or arrows stolen from attackers, or impaling your hapless opponent on a fallen weapon. Weapons and passive special abilities can increase your range or set up free combos on groups of enemies, so you always need to be looking for those openings. The pace of the game is enthralling, and once you learn to keep up with it every level becomes a whirlwind of broken spines and flying bodies. It's like a rhythm game where every beat kills a person.

Battles can take a minute or less, so the developers smartly included hundreds upon hundreds of levels and modes to enjoy. The main game has a world map with hundreds of stages across multiple paths, including time attacks, survival rounds, weapon stages using nunchakus and not-lightsabers, boss battles, and sepia-toned retro film battles. Some paths unlock new passive skills as well, such as longer weapon durations and free hits. There are three difficulties on top of that, and a host of survival modes to challenge as well. Of particular note is a genius difficulty system that adjusts as you play: Every time you win a battle, the game's pace increases slightly, and when you lose it drops back down. There's no incentive to keeping the pace high, it just keeps the game at a difficulty appropriate to you.

I really cannot stress enough how viscerally fun it is to murder hundreds of stick dudes, and the vast amount of stages and modes to murder them in makes this an ideal package. Games like One Finger Death Punch deserve special recognition for creating a simple, enjoyable gameplay concept, and then giving you nigh-infinite permutations of it. If you like fast-paced action you're sure to love this, and there's enough to love to keep you busy for weeks on end.

I'm nowhere near beating the game yet and I already got my moneys worth. But if it wasn't for TotalBiscuit's positive review I wouldn't have bought it. I'm sure Ben Yahtzee Crowshaw will like it if he bothers to review it. The only flaws I can find are the no options menu and the fact that you need to have the reflexes of a cheetah and the patience of a rock to get Perfect 0 Misses. But that only brings it down to a 9.75/10. It's very satisfying. You need to lose half of your brain to not like this game.

reviewText: One Finger Death Punch is an addictive, fast paced, somewhat silly, smile-inducing homage to kung fu movies.  This is what happens if Bruce Lee & Jackie Chan made a Stick Fighter video game.  2D and side scrolling it may be, but this is no a hinderance at all.  The gameplay is akin to rhythm matching with one hand, but the action is so much more fun to watch.  As I play, I find my smile getting cramped and tired from being there so long.  The memories of my misspent youth watching Kung Fu movies on Saturday afternoons comes flooding back with every bone cracking, eye-popping, heart-bursting hit.  :D\n\nIn short, this is the most fun you can have with one hand and tell your mom about it.

reviewText: This game is brilliant.  When I first saw this game I was thinking it was going to be a massive button smasher, but one of the first things the game says is that if you button mash you will die.  This is so true. As you play the game the difficulty gets progressively harder with not only the difficulty of certain enemies but with an indicator that either speeds up the attackers or slows them down based off how well you are doing.  The more you succeed the faster the attackers attack and also the more you fail the slower the attackers come at you. At first this sounded to be a hand holding method, but it is quite smooth and is very noticeable when you go from a very easy level to a much harder level. I would have a much faster speed from dominating the easier level and then get dominated from the harder levels.  Another plus about this game is that it is a very friendly to a lower end PC. Works just fine on my 7 year old laptop. However the only real complaint is that the over world used to the basic adventure portion of the game is a little hard to get used to. It is slightly difficult to be able to move from level to level. This is only a small draw back due to the fact that it is quickly forgotten when you are very satisfactory decimating many stick figures with amazingly fluid response and in many respects this made me feel like I was the main character.  Great game and hope you are able to enjoy this as much as I did.

reviewText:
I've got a bunch of time on a game with only two buttons and such a simple idea. But the way that idea was enacted was very, very well made.

One finger death punch is a Fast-Paced Action game where enemies come at you from both sides. The enemies are not always the same though. There is the normal gray 1 punch, 1 kill enemies, but there are also colored enemies that will take multiple attacks before they are finally taken down. You have special attacks in a cooldown system which requires you to kill enemies to put them to use. there are also weapons that are occasionally dropped by enemies waiting for them to be picked up or used in a special way. There are sword type weapons that give you extra range to hit enemies, but there are bows and daggers that are ranged attacks, and a ball of death that you punch multiple times to take out enemies. The game is easy to learn but difficult to master.

As a PC gamer, graphics are important to me, but considering this is an indie dev, I could let a little bit slide. The graphics are definitely far from impressive, everything is 2d figures that contrast from where you are in the game, and all the sprites are just colored stick-figures. Other than that, the animations are very flashy and impressive. There are multiple fighting styles which changes the way your stick-figure looks like when he fights, and is very satisfying when you amputate an enemy with a weapon.

There are multiple game-modes but after the while they start to feel very repetitive, but thanks to the learning curve, they are always challenging.

One finger Death Punch is a great game with a few problems, but are very overlooked to it's flawless combat and satisfying weapons

For it's price, this game deserves a 9/10

reviewText:
I'm gonna go for the 'Sam Spade in the Maltese Falcon' method of reviewing this game: I'm going to explain all the reasons why I don't want to recommend it, and then I'm going to explain why I WILL recommend it.

So here's a big old 'Reasons for No Recommendation' list:

- The UI is functional garbage and has all the gravitas of an early 2000's 'I bought Macromedia Dreamweaver 3 at Goodwill and I'm gonna build the best website ever, watch out world' Geocities page.
- The narrator is racist as hell.
- The game absolutely refuses to remember my settings, so every time I open up the game I have to tell the game to stop using my gamepad, then I have to click on the right arrow a number of times to shut the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing narrator up.
- Seriously, can we talk about why the game absolutely refuses to remember my settings? I don't know why the game absolutely refuses to remember the things I tell it, and then it goes and tells me what the light sword round is all about, despite the fact that I've kicked so many asses with that sword that my sword is more ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• than sword now. Like the game has perpetual amnesia.
- Completionist bait re: so many ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• achievements for a game that's just about stoving in the heads of dudes who dare to run blindly towards your fist.
- Why not call it Two Finger Death Punch? (Nitpicking at this point, time to move on.)

Those are all the reasons I don't recommend it. Here's why I do:

- Round lengths are PERFECT. Not too long, not too short, just right. All you need is a couple of minutes to lay waste to a crowd of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s and at the end you'll feel like you've really accomplished something. It taps into that same bloodlust euphoria that Hotline Miami taps into really well.
- It gets its sexy so right. The player feedback for punching a dude dead is phenomenal. There's enough variations in the death sequences where you get to see a dude's ribs crack or an eyeball fly or pinning a dude to the ground with your sword to heighten the awesomeness. The tempo the game keeps is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing wonderful.
- As you get better, the game gets faster, and it keeps challenging you and you have to answer the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing call by being faster and more precise or it shames you by making the game move slower.
- The ability to one-hit kill bosses with thrown weapons is awesome and I really wish more games would do it more often.
- The game can make you feel like a badass, but the included No Luca No Survival mode makes this hilarious. This is because in the midst of frenetic kung-fu badass action, the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• cat walks in front of the screen and shoving it away makes The Whiniest Cat Owner In The World whine at his cat, which hits so embarrasingly close to home that it becomes hilarious.

All of these reasons make my 'No Recommendation' list pale in absolute comparison. Yeah, sure, I really wish there wasn't a narrator at all and the game does things that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• me off, but those things are mere hurdles in the way of endlessly satisfying amounts of kicking the asses of dudes. You have to play this and accept the flaws, racist narrators and non-working settings and all. It's worth it.

reviewText: Instantly addictive and pure, concentrated fun. A title with such ridiculously simple gameplay shouldn't be this enjoyable, but the two-man team at Silver Dollar Games really pulled off a thing of genius with One Finger Death Punch. It's pretty much just as simple as pressing the left mouse button to attack left and the right mouse button to attack right, but there's something irresistible about how that mechanic mixes with the visuals to deliver something utterly satisfying and hopelessly addictive. It's been years since I've played a game and said to myself, Alright
hoursPlayed: only to find myself still playing hours later. If the game has one shortcoming, it's that its visuals leave something to be desired, although I can appreciate that it draws inspiration from the old Xiao Xiao animations. My interest in this game was initially very low, but I'm glad I tried it. This will probably be one of the little gems on Steam that I end up going to for a quick fix of fun for years to come.

reviewText:
As a graphic designer, it is my job and passion to make things look nice. As a gamer, one of the things I love most is the possibility to explore gorgeously designed and rendered worlds with strong aesthetic sensibilities. What I'm trying to say is: I stay the hell away from games that look like One Finger Death Punch.

I'm glad I made an exception and gave it a try, though. REALLY glad. Because disgusting as it looks, it is incredibly fun and addictive to play. The mechanics are simple, but despite only having two buttons to press, you feel very much in control. It also is challenging. And mastering that challenge? Oh, it is just such fun. I found myself immediately replaying levels and trying to go for the best ranking. Additionally, the game does a great job in keeping things fresh and switching them up, expanding on the core gameplay in many different ways - not changing it, but simply taking on it from different perspectives. All throughout, this is a showcase of incredibly clever game design, and looking at Silver Dollar Games' questionable previous game catalogue, I have to wonder if they sold their soul to the devil to accomplish what they have with One Finger Death Punch.

And for what it's worth? It's cheesy aesthetics fit what it's trying to do. I think the engrish voiceovers won me over. Which I guess really just leaves me with one point of critique: Way too freaking many achievements.

reviewText:
A long time ago, there were those little flashvideos where a little a single stickfigure beat the living ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of a group of stickfigure enemies. And now we finally got this in Video Game Form.
The creators of the videos and this game are not the same,but the idea is very similar. You get a stickfigure to control on the middle of the screen and use the left and right mouse button to smash your opponent on your left or right side. Don't take it easily because you only have two button for the entire game. The strength of this lies in the difficulty to beat those figures. Some of them need more than one hit to go down and can even switch sides, which makes mindless buttonmashing a death sentence.

Gameplay

In general, this game discourages you to just mash the poor button. One Finger Death Punch 01Similar to the Kung Fu Fighting movies some enemies need a complex succession of punches, or in this case 2 cicks left 2 clicks right before ist over. But beware my friend. Some Opponents with more than just 1 HP tend to switch side if you hit them and you could miss if you don't watch carefully and that makes you stunned for a short time and vulnerable for a counterattack. Luckily the devs are good guys and colored the enemies after their movement pattern. Green ones stays on one side no matter how much you hit them, orange ones switch sides after every strike.
During the course of the game you can get abilites like healing or freezing all enemies on one side, which get activated after a certain body count. A nice feature, but you can go through the game even without this. You get these abilities unlocked in adventure mode where you travel the land on a game board to finally meet and beat your master. The board itself contains various challanges you need to win in order to progress. The challenges get a little repitive after a while, especially the standart challenge where just have to beat a certain amount of enemies without special restrictions.


One Finger Death Punch 02The last point in Gameplay I find worth a notice are weapons. It ranges from swords to maces to bows and does nothig more than inreasing your attack range. But if you already hold a weapon and grab another one you can throw the second one like a dealy projectile and hit multiple enemies at once. It's another story with ranged weapons of course. You just stand there and shoot it in the direction you're pressing.


Music & Sound

The game has several music tracks to offer, depending on which challange you currently take on. Nothing special, but adds a nice atmosphere.
A far better job at achieving an atmosphere is doing your chinese master who is speaking from beyond your game and explaining part of the menu and the objectives of the challenges, if you want it or not. Which is a little negative aspect on it, because after a dozen times you know how this challenge works and you just want him to shut up.

Conclusion

Did you wanted to feel like Bruce Lee or are you just mad at something and want to hurt someone, this is the game for you. For anyone else you have a pretty solid casual game on hand. A simple yet addictive gameplay, interesting challenges, the wish to beat the highscore and over 150 achievement can keep you going for a while. Though it can get frustrating sometimes.


If you want to get a better look at a playthrough of this game just click the link below:
http://youtu.be/vC7w2TVh8jE?list=UUMxIS2guRxfCuJ1gllMecuA

For more Reviews visit my Blog at:
http://achievementunlockblog.wordpress.com/home/

reviewText:
This game is amazing!  I could go on, but you only need to know one thing:

YOU CAN HIT PEOPLE WITH A MASSIVE FISH!!  10/10!

Scott Shaw would be proud.

Anyways, this is an extremely fun, twitch-tastic game, obviously reminiscent of the classic Xiao Xiao Flash animations from the earlier days of the internet, where stick figures using martial arts would beat the crap out of each other.  While some of them were games, they were never very long, so this game feels like an epic Xiao Xiao quest!

The controls are pretty unique, as this game DEMANDS to be played in a certain way.  The game will tell you that button-mashing will not work.  Instead, you're given two buttons (either mouse buttons or a pair of keys on the keyboard) that allow you to attack to the left or the right.  At first, not being able to move may seem limiting, as you wait for bad guys to line up for fist sandwiches, but once you get the hang of how it works, you suddenly understand what they were going for.

What they wanted was a game that made you feel" like a martial arts master
date: and I think they totally pulled it off quite well.  By having the game be based on timed-inputs
recommended: you fall into a zen-like rhythm as you gracefully pound your opponents into gooey bits.  (Of course

reviewText:
One finger death punch caught me completely off guard.

I expected a casual time waster and what I got was a somewhat shallow but very solid and entertaining two button fighting game. This game is much more difficult to play in later levels than it may initially appear from screenshots and trailers.

This game might bring much nostalgia to you if you were around Newgrounds during the days that Xiao Xiao was really popular, because this is very much a spiritual successor to it.

It has a nice learning curve and is easy to pick up but somewhat difficult to truly master. For completionists out there, you might like the fact that it has a medal system. While it may seem easy to get a platinum medal for the first few missions, the difficulty ramps up with each campaign mission. Here's where my one and only complaint with the game comes from. While it occasionally varies it's many missions up with laser sword, crash, and numchuck missions, after a short while of playing it can feel very samey. Which isn't a bad thing because the game is addictive as all hell, but you might want to play in short bursts for maximum enjoyment.

For $5? This game is definitely worth it, it's highly entertaining, replayable and very addictive. A survival mode in any game for me is a huge plus and this game has three different kinds of survival modes (Well, technically two, the third one is just regular survival with a giant cat obscuring one side of your screen), one of which tests your game knowledge by taking away all visual cues except for enemy color. Before I knew it I had played this game for 3 or so hours even though I intended to play it for around 1 or so.

reviewText:
The controls are simple.
The gameplay is simple.
The graphics are simple.

Bottom line though? The game is fun.

The stages which stop you from using skills (nunchuck and lightsaber rounds especially since enemies in those don't even have variation) are boring as get out. Without special skills this game loses the qualities that stop it from becoming mind numbingly repetitive. I think I lose in those stages a lot purely because I zone out from boredom.

My thoughts during those rounds tend to go something like this:
left left right right right right left right left left left left left left left right right right left right right left left left left right right right rght right right wow I've killed about 150 guys and not enjoyed it this is getting boring and repetitive I wonder if --ohshit I died"

With skills and various weapons the game is still simple but there's variation in the combat enough to keep it stimulating. Whether it's throwing weapons
recommended:
jumping and shaking the earth to knock everything out... you know. Whatever. It makes it more than repetitively performing one attack the entire round.

To be fair the first time I saw the light saber it had a moment of sweetness. Mostly just because the first time I saw it it was new and I was wondering what was going to go on. I mean come on; it was a light saber! There was nothing to it really though. The gameplay in that round is numbingly simple - just pure normal attacks. I'd rather be able to just disable the rounds that turn skills off but you can't skip all of them.

I did enjoy most of the game. There are many fighting styles incorporated into this. The game teaches how to play short and sweet at the beginning of any level with something new added with a quick voiceover of what I guess is the sensei. And there are a surprising amount of skills you can find and use in a game that's so simple.

I'd give this a 5/10. It's a simple game. There's clearly effort in it
hoursPlayed: but ultimately the claim they make (being "We believe being an indie game company means we can focus on gameplay instead of graphics") falls flat on it's face since it lacked much in terms of graphics AND gameplay - especially once skills were removed for half of the stages in the game. To be fair it's not an overdone concept so they aren't exactly borrowing from others.\n\nIn terms of fun I think it definintly has it's moments. Certain stages."

reviewText: This game is brilliant.  When I first saw this game I was thinking it was going to be a massive button smasher, but one of the first things the game says is that if you button mash you will die.  This is so true. As you play the game the difficulty gets progressively harder with not only the difficulty of certain enemies but with an indicator that either speeds up the attackers or slows them down based off how well you are doing.  The more you succeed the faster the attackers attack and also the more you fail the slower the attackers come at you. At first this sounded to be a hand holding method, but it is quite smooth and is very noticeable when you go from a very easy level to a much harder level. I would have a much faster speed from dominating the easier level and then get dominated from the harder levels.  Another plus about this game is that it is a very friendly to a lower end PC. Works just fine on my 7 year old laptop. However the only real complaint is that the over world used to the basic adventure portion of the game is a little hard to get used to. It is slightly difficult to be able to move from level to level. This is only a small draw back due to the fact that it is quickly forgotten when you are very satisfactory decimating many stick figures with amazingly fluid response and in many respects this made me feel like I was the main character.  Great game and hope you are able to enjoy this as much as I did.

reviewText: If you remember those flash-based animations from the Internet‚Äôs yesteryears (like XiaoXiao), then One Finger Death Punch will look immediately familiar. You control a stick figure martial arts master, fighting an onslaught of enemies that appear from the sides of the screen. You only use two buttons, left and right mouse buttons, to attack enemies on the left and right of your character. It sounds simply, but One Finger Death Punch masterfully layers increasingly complex situations until eventually you either die like a punk or stand tall as a totally badass kung fu master.\n\nWith great visual feedback for each hit, a variety of weapons that you can turn against their wielders, and just straight-up solid-feeling gameplay, this is one of those little games you just can‚Äôt put down. When in the middle of a fight, chaining together combos and not even seeing the colour-coded hints on which buttons to press, there‚Äôs a great zen-like moment where you‚Äôre just‚Ä¶ rocking. The game might not look all that great from a distance (or even up close), and people might disregard it as cheap, but they‚Äôd be passing up something unique that practically anyone can play. Although the cartoon violence might not be suitable for really young kids.

reviewText:
One finger death punch caught me completely off guard.

I expected a casual time waster and what I got was a somewhat shallow but very solid and entertaining two button fighting game. This game is much more difficult to play in later levels than it may initially appear from screenshots and trailers.

This game might bring much nostalgia to you if you were around Newgrounds during the days that Xiao Xiao was really popular, because this is very much a spiritual successor to it.

It has a nice learning curve and is easy to pick up but somewhat difficult to truly master. For completionists out there, you might like the fact that it has a medal system. While it may seem easy to get a platinum medal for the first few missions, the difficulty ramps up with each campaign mission. Here's where my one and only complaint with the game comes from. While it occasionally varies it's many missions up with laser sword, crash, and numchuck missions, after a short while of playing it can feel very samey. Which isn't a bad thing because the game is addictive as all hell, but you might want to play in short bursts for maximum enjoyment.

For $5? This game is definitely worth it, it's highly entertaining, replayable and very addictive. A survival mode in any game for me is a huge plus and this game has three different kinds of survival modes (Well, technically two, the third one is just regular survival with a giant cat obscuring one side of your screen), one of which tests your game knowledge by taking away all visual cues except for enemy color. Before I knew it I had played this game for 3 or so hours even though I intended to play it for around 1 or so.

reviewText:
This game is phenomenal, cheap and a MUST BUY.

The game begins easy at the start and gradually works its way up to being actually quite challenging; especially on the later levels. The range of enemies that require different fighting 'patterns' and the wide variety and types of levels keeps things fresh and always keeps you on your toes so that you never really play the same level the same way.
Because each level in itself is reasonably short you can play them in short bursts during your lunch breaks without having to worry about getting half-way through and having to quit and lose huge amounts of progress. Alternatively you can try and master through all the levels in a weekend or day off; perfect for stress relief.

The 'mastery' and perfection system in this game is also another reason I'd highly recommend it. Each level you play through awards you medals from nothing to the all sacred 'perfect medal' for a flawless game. For someone like myself who loves a challenge, this mechanic is amazing because I could play the same level 10+ times aiming for the elusive flawless game, still miss it and not care because I was having too much fun to care.

But what really works well in this game is it's adaptive difficulty. But, what's that?
Well, if you're kicking bad guys asses too often and blazing through the levels super quick or just generally finding the game too easy, the enemies will get faster and harder to predict until you ultimately get your asses kicked instead (which actually makes for a lot of chaotic fun).
And yet, if you're having trouble passing a level because they run at you too fast or you just can't get the patterns right the game will slow 'em down a little for you and give you a little breathing room... but don't expect it to hold your hand.


tl;dr
What other game can make you feel like an awesome kung-fu master kicking bad guys asses using only two buttons? Answer: Nothing, BUY IT NOW!

reviewText:
I cannot even begin to describe how awesomely fun this game is.  You'd expect a lot less from Silver Dollar Games, makers of endless shovelware for XBLA and PC, with gems like Outbreak on Uranus, Who's the Daddy 1 and 2, Don't Be Nervous Talking to Girls, and the perennial favorite, Try Not to Fart.

With a track record like that, you'd be absolutely forgiven for thinking that One Finger Death Punch (OFDP) would be yet another pebble in the doodoo pile, but in every honking pile of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• is a kernel of greatness - OFDP is the gleaming piece of corn that stands out and probably makes you laugh.

Like most great games, the core mechanic is simple - LMB attacks left, RMB attacks right.  There is nothing else for you to do in the game.  On the surface, it seems shallow and stupid - like almost all of Silver Dollar's back catalog - but there is some serious twitch action to be found and surprising depth from a game that uses only two buttons.

Your character, the kung fooeyist of kung fu masters, stands in the middle of the field as endless waves of baddies rush in to attack him (or her - it's a stick person).  Beneath each baddie is a clue on how to defeat them; most are single-punch dismissals, but as you progress through the hundred levels (spread in 3 difficulties), they become more clever, have weapons, dodge your initial attacks, require multiple hits, swing from side to side, engage you in furious clicky duels, and so on and so forth.  Soon enough, you start a mob round" and see there's 200 guys you need to combo and you don't want to miss a single hit if you're going to get that platinum medal.  But even if you're not the perfectionist
date: there's plenty of challenges for you to overcome
hoursPlayed: and fantastic slaughterfest weapon levels (light sword levels are awesome).\n\nIs it worth $5?  That's subjective.  I picked it up in a bundle and have been playing it non-stop.  I've paid more for less.  If it means Silver Dollar Games will continue to make actual good games

reviewText:
I just want to lay some ground rules here before we start... You have to be dedicated, there's no way you can expect to finish or halfway finish on the whim that you feel like it. This is a journey, you're in, or you quit. Second, this I will defend this game to my grave. And third, there is no third. Now, onto this horridly long review, this'll be fun.

I do believe I understand a thing or two about this game, just check my achevements and I've compleated Grandmaster mode, which is no walk in the park. let me start you off with the basics, you press to the right, you kill the enemy to your right, you press to the left, you kill the enemy to the left. you fight an enemy with more than one hit, you hit him again either right or left. Very basic, and this basic combat system does not change throughout the entirety of the game. Reading this after the other reviews, you know this becomes less simple, and levels become increasingly difficult. I'll just tell you that this is how the game is played, it can't be done another way. Another basic is the map, you start from the left side, and you fight your way to the right, collecting power-ups and skills along with increased combat experience all the way. The last basic this you need to know is not distract youself. I know this sounds easy but losing your focus can cost you life, maybe even your own...

Now that you know the basics, lets explore the game. The game's level types are:
Mob rounds (The most common and the core of the game)
Speed rounds (Basically Mob rounds but to see how fast you can do them)
Boss Rounds (You find these all over the place and they're difficult)
Light Sword and Nunchuku Rounds (The player's worst nightmare on the higher speeds, the Nunchuku rounds are easier)
Retro Film Rounds (There to make the brawler fights harder)
Thuderstorm Rounds (Something I can't wrap my head around as hard because of the change in colors, or a gift because the brawlers or non-existant, anyways, these are hard too)
Dagger, Bomb, Defender rounds (I f****** hate these rounds. thery're fast and if you mess up ONE TIME YOU DIE!!!)
Smash rounds (Basically survive until the game is over, the fake objective is to smash enemies into objects)
Survival rounds (You can skip these)
And Finally, the Multi-Rounds, i think these are easy because there are little enimies and you memorize them after doing it over and over again)
Now, you can't have levels without any enimies now can you...
There are several combinations of enemies, most enemies can be killed with a sigle hit, others are a bit more unique. Oh, and all enimies are capable of holding wepons (We'll cover that later)
Gray (one shot, one kill enemies)
Colored enemies... (There's a space under them to show you how to react to them).. too vague? well how about you memorize all the colors of enemies??? Oh O.K. I'll try to remember...
Green (Hit two times in their direction to kill them))
Blue (Hit towards them once, hit the other way once)
This is where there become too many colors, just know they have up to four hits.
Brawlers (You learn to dislike these guys because you don't know how many hits they have. When you hit these enemies you have to kill them before you can fight another enemy)
Warning, this next message could be classified as spoiler, scroll over at your own risk. ?"  (You can never tell how many hits these guys have. Exclusive to the end of Master and During Grandmaster mode)
Thrower (Gray enemies whose soul purpose is to toss a wepon that upon capture can be thrown at other enemies. It is pointless to attempt killing these enemies because not only do they move along with the edge of the screen
date: but because their wepon counts as their kill)\nBoss enemies (no different from normal color enemies except they are exclusive to Boss rounds and after completion of ther hits continually spawn new ones until the health bar at the top of the screen is depleated)\nThese are the wepons in this game
recommended: wepons are either picked up from killed enemies

You only use two buttons, left and right mouse buttons, to attack enemies on the left and right of your character. It sounds simply, but One Finger Death Punch masterfully layers increasingly complex situations until eventually you either die like a punk or stand tall as a totally badass kung fu master.\n\nWith great visual feedback for each hit, a variety of weapons that you can turn against their wielders, and just straight-up solid-feeling gameplay, this is one of those little games you just can‚Äôt put down. When in the middle of a fight, chaining together combos and not even seeing the colour-coded hints on which buttons to press, there‚Äôs a great zen-like moment where you‚Äôre just‚Ä¶ rocking. The game might not look all that great from a distance (or even up close), and people might disregard it as cheap, but they‚Äôd be passing up something unique that practically anyone can play. Although the cartoon violence might not be suitable for really young kids.

reviewText:
One Finger Death Punch is an action game produced by Silver Dollar Games and it was released in early 2014.

There's good reason for my lightning-fast reflexes, and how I excel at video games, and how no one can surprise me with a baseball bat from behind: I play One Finger Death Punch.

If your bored with your current game library and dont want to pay 30-60 $ on a game that will entertain you for a good while or you just want to try something fresh and different from all the survival games coming out lately, One Finger Death Punch is the game for you! It has HOURS AND HOURS of gameplay with almost endless replayability!

I bought this game thinking I would probably play it for a week or two but I am completely hooked. When I'm bored of other games or I dont have the time to play games like ARK: Survival Evolved or H1Z1 I hop onto OFDP thinking I am only gonna play a few levels then I'm done, but a few minutes later, soon turns into A FEW HOURS...

If you want something fresh in your Steam Library to play then why not get One Finger Death Punch! It's EXTREMELY fun and addicting and only cost 5$!!!

reviewText:
I'm tempted to write a simple, tongue-in-cheek review like the ones that seem to be popular here on Steam:

This game wore out my mouse (true story).
11/10

But that wouldn't do One Finger Death Punch justice. This is a game that fits the description of greater than the sum of all its parts." With no story
date: stick figure visuals and two button controls
recommended: how could this be great? My answer: perfection in tailored difficulty and breakneck speed action. This game consistently throws at you the most exhilarating level of challenge without crossing over into frustration. Are you tired and sluggish today? No problem
hoursPlayed: the kung-fu will slow down to match you. Just loaded up on coffee? Don't get cocky because as fast as you go
voteText: this game will keep up.\n\nIt is precisely because of the two button control scheme that One Finger Death Punch is able to be such a fast paced game. I applaud the developers for finding this strength in what otherwise seems like a weak choice for controls. Similar praise could be given to the visuals. They're far from AAA quality but they're vibrant
helpfulPercent: fluid and joyously violent enough to work. The sound is deliciously impactful as you smash enemies through walls or cut them down with a light sword. I would have welcomed more tracks on the soundtrack but what is there fits the quick tempo of the combat. The announcer
votesHelpful: while campy
votesTotal: is as fun to listen to as his accent is over-the-top. I'd also like to highlight the hilarious "No Luca No" survival mode that adds a nice human (and feline) touch to the game.\n\nAll this adds up to a game that is entertaining through and through."

reviewText: This was a huge suprise to me, but this game is a ton of fun to play. It is exremely satisfying to play and to do well on, as each hit has a very satisfying feel to it. This game is one of the best examples of how simple mechanics do not equal a simple, basic experience. reviewText:
This game is the first rhythm game, I enjoyed.
In this game you only have two controls - the left and right mouse button, which make your character either attak to the left or right. With these basics you'll have to fight hords of other stickmans.
And there are a lot of ways to kill a stickman, my favourite being throwing an enemy into the air and let them land on your weapon - IMPALEEEED!!!
The variety of fight moves, which 'unlock' by getting combos, weapons and different kinds of levels keep you playing for a while. Although after you experienced all levels, they'll get only harder and frustrating, but very rewarding.
I think this is one of the hidden gems in the rythm genre and is a must-have, highly recommended.
This game gets a 'A' for Awesome (A>G>O)

EDIT: The soundtrack is pretty damn good and fully worth the prize, in case you don't enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Fast-paced, simple, and surprisingly addictive.  Don't be put off by Newgrounds-esque game art, this is an well thought out game that is a shining example of what can be done when when developers know what they're doing and stick to what they know best.

Recently, many indie studios have, instead of starting with a simple proof-of-concept, jump headlong into what they intend to be a ground-breaking masterpiece.  The vast majority of the time, as to be expected, they miss, shooting themselves in the foot while shooting for the stars.  Silver Dollar Games knew what they were doing here.  They knew their budget was limited, they knew they weren't Rembrandt, so instead of trying their hands at something they knew they couldn't do, they instead focused on solid gameplay.

That's basically what this game boils down to, a fantastic twitch-based brawler hidden behind a mediocre art-style.  If you know what's good for you, give this game a try; it's WELL worth your time and $5.

reviewText: Never really been a big player of indie games.  Many of them just dont grab my attention.  So I saw a video of this on youtube and it seemed interesting so I gave it a try. Do yourself a favor and pick this up.

reviewText:
Well, I'm certainly impressed.

This game has fewer controls than space invaders (equal with non analogue pong) but provides so much visceral satisfaction through an endless stream of positive feedback in the form of insane stick fighting from hell that it borders very closely on getting a warning instead of a recommendation as it will simply suck time from you like you wouldn't believe.

The fact that it IS the kind of game anyone can play but has a skill ceiling up there with something like Simon means that all I can do is say again - it's cheap as chips and deserves your attention so give it a go.  (please note that I accept no responsibility for any loss of otherwise important attention that may result from this game taking all of it.)

reviewText:
A really fun and simple game. Despite the hilariously simple controls and how-to, some of the levels can get really fast-paced and crazy. I'd recommend this to anyone who just wants some easy and frantic fun.

Being able to unleash your inner kung-fu enthusiast while bashing, slashing, and stabbing through veritable armies of stickmen is certainly worth the small price tag. That goes double if you catch it on sale.

reviewText:
For $5, or $2.5 right now, you really need this game.

It's hideous, but it doesn't matter, it still looks and feels cool to watch your little stickman do awesome stuff. It has this satisfying feeling due to the fact that the controls are immediate. That every button press is hugely significant and that it does exactly what you expect it to; punch a dude's head off.

It's a game you gain a bunch of satisfaction from getting really good at, much like another game I love, Spelunky. They're totally different, they're both just challenging as hell. But I think the kidn of eprson who takes joy in becoming awesome at a game like that will love this game.

It's also a game you can just spend a couple hours on and be happy. It's concentrated fun and even if you don't fall in love with it you will not regret the purchase, especially on sale or in a bundle.

The only segment of gamers this game isn't for are those who literally only care about story. It has none. Literally, none. It doesn't even pretend. But that's not a con.

It's levels of various kinds of punch all these dudes' heads off" then the occasional boss level
recommended: I say one...) awesome dude. And to me that made a really epic (in the proper sense) narrative in and of itself. It let me create my own daydreams. Give my stickman (who I named Chow Yun Stick) backstory. I imagine that boss's name is Tao Lin and he killed my brother Fa Long and we were jsut simple farmers but then I swore vengeance and trained ofr years and meanwhile he became the head of the Triad and now I must punch through his minions to avenge my brother and OHMYGODAWESOME.\n\nAlso
voteText: one of the devs appears and talks to you
helpfulPercent: and thanks you profusely for playing his game. He even does it in text between levels. Those guys will be REALLY thankful to you if you buy this game. It's really adorable. It made me want to buy it again 'cause it just seemed like they really needed it. Like they're literally a studio with one silver dollar to their names."

reviewText: Never really been a big player of indie games.  Many of them just dont grab my attention.  So I saw a video of this on youtube and it seemed interesting so I gave it a try. I get more satisifaction landing combos playing this then most triple A, high budget fighting titles.  Dont be fooled.  This is not a button mashing game.  Each mouse click needs to be timed correctly in order to succesfully land a attack.  Its easy enough for my non-gamer wife to enjoy and challenging enough for someone like me to keep me interested.  Do yourself a favor and pick this up.

reviewText:
What can I say.  This game is AMAZING.  The team at Silver Dollar has done what many companies strive for but few have succeeded in.  They have made a game of simplicity and pure fun.  From the beginning to the end this game delivers.

From the moment you start up the game one thing is very clear.  This game has a personality, and that personality is awesome.  With an epic soundtrack that would make any Shaw Bros. kung fu movie of old jealous you are emersed in a journey through intense kung fu battles all via your simple stick figure avatar.

The controls are just as simple as the graphics, and there is a beauty in that regards that many big budget games seem to overlook.  You don't need fancy GPU instensive graphics to have fun.  You just need fun to have fun.  From silly death animations to a variety of incredible levels involving light swords, nunchucks, thrunderstorms, and retro film themes you are a  kung fu master, and often I found myself just laughing and smiling through countless sessions and levels.

In addition to this fast paced action world of wonder the devs have even taken it one step further by adding numerous levels and game modes for you to enjoy in increasing difficulty.  Not only is the game immensely fun, but it's also challenging and hard as you progress.  The depth and skill curve is accurately balanced as the game adjusts to your speed of difficulty finding that perfect calibration to your skill level.

There is no doubt that this is a special title.  It's not often that you get to experience a game like this, but even in your last moments of hardship in the game the devs are right there sending you a sword from the heavens as if to say We know you might not make it
date: but take this.. we believe in you".   I haven't had this kind of experience playing a game in a long long time.  It's nothing but pure joy
recommended: and a title I would recommend to anyone looking for a game that is fun

reviewText:
Quick Breakdown: A highly addictive rhythmic brawler, with simplistic gameplay that loads of fun.
Length: 6+ hours (Main game)
Score: 8/10

Full Review: One Finger Death Punch (from here on OFDP) is a pretty simple and straightforward game. It‚Äôs a 2D brawler that uses only two mouse buttons (or keys depending on your preference), and all its characters are simple stick figures. Enemies come at you from both sides of the screen, while you remain in the middle. You can‚Äôt move, you instead must wait for enemies to come close enough to be in range, once they are you either tap left or right according to which side they are on to attack.

Before we delve further into the gameplay, let‚Äôs quickly go over the controls. The game instructs you to use only the left and right mouse buttons, and as the name implies, you‚Äôre supposed to do so using only one finger. However, I found I preferred using two fingers, one on each button more. More than that, I didn‚Äôt actually use the mouse to play more than a few levels to test it. While the game makes no mention of it, you can also use the left and right arrow keys, or the A and D keys (of WASD fame) to play. The game however does not allow you to remap the controls at all. Thankfully though, using two fingers and the arrow keys worked wonderfully for me and I‚Äôd have not remapped even if I could.

The gameplay features two modes, level and survival. Level mode will introduce you to the basics of the game, so let‚Äôs talk about that first.

I already talked about waiting for enemies to move into range, and how to attack, so we‚Äôll not go over that again. As for attacking, you want to avoid button mashing, as it‚Äôll cause you to miss. Missing makes you more likely to be hit by an enemy, as your character has a brief pause after missing before being able to attack again. Since you only have a limited amount of health for each level (usually 10 HP, but it varies by the level, sometimes only a single HP). If you manage to complete a level without being hit, you will receive a perfect. You will also receive a medal depending on how many times you missed. 0 earns you a platinum, 1-3 a gold, 4-6 a silver, 7-9 a bronze, and 10+ won‚Äôt net you a medal at all.  Achieving perfects and medals will not earn you anything in the game, but chances are you‚Äôll keep replaying many levels until you get a perfect and a platinum medal.

When you first start the game, enemies will consist of simple one hit enemies and brawlers. Brawlers are a special type of enemy that brings you into a fight against just that one enemy, consisting of various left and right strikes (the rest of the level momentarily is tuned out until after you defeat the brawler). As the game progress brawlers will have longer sequences of left and right, and more enemy types will appear. Now, there isn‚Äôt great variety in the enemy types, mostly it consists of the enemies requiring more hits to be defeated, and the order for the button presses needed to defeat them (some enemies dodge to the other side of your character after being hit). All the enemies are colour coded, so you can simply glance at them to determine the number of hits and order of the attack. Not keen on memorizing that? No need to worry, there will be coloured bars beneath each enemy indicating the order of the hits. Blue bars mean you click to the left, and red bars mean a click to the right, with the order of the bars going from top to bottom.

What‚Äôs surprising is just how satisfying it is too mow down your enemies. But punching through hordes of coloured stick people does feel satisfying, with each hit you land providing a satisfying crunch. And the occasional gory death shot that randomly occurs is a nice touch as well.

As you plow through your stick figured foes, sometimes they‚Äôll drop weapons that you can use to aid you in your fight. Melee weapons like swords and maces extend your range of attack, but can only be used for a limited amount of time. Ranged weapons like arrows, daggers, and bombs can be thrown across the screen to kill any enemy in a single hit, regardless of their health. You‚Äôll only get one of a ranged weapon at a time though (unless you use are using a skill that causes you to pick up 3 at a time, but we‚Äôll talk more about skills in a bit).

As you progress through the game you‚Äôll encounter different types of stages. The bulk of your gameplay will be done in melee stages, which are just a simple assault of different enemies. You‚Äôll also have special weapons rounds, in which you wield either a light sword or nunchucks, as you‚Äôre assaulted by a quick barrage of single hit enemies. Speed rounds impose a time limit upon you, requiring you to be swift in your punching. Multi rounds will have you play the same short wave of enemies multiple times in a row, with an increase in speed each time. Survival rounds test to see how many enemies you can defeat before you are killed (and always reward you with a victory, regardless of how well you do). There are other types of levels as well.

Levels are selected from a map screen, which is frankly horrid. It‚Äôs not that I have issue with the map screen, but it‚Äôs just simply god-awful. It‚Äôs ugly to look at, does not allow you to scroll, instead forcing you to navigate by clicking on levels, which is overly cumbersome when trying to go to a level that‚Äôs 2 screens away. The map features branching paths for the levels, but there‚Äôs little rhyme or reason to the different paths, just levels thrown on each that are gradually increasing in difficulty, rendering the map largely pointless ‚Äìsave from an excursion down a side path that leads to a dead end containing  a skill.

Speaking of skills, let‚Äôs talk about those now. As you play through the game you‚Äôll be able to procure various skills from certain levels as a reward for their completion. Skills may be equipped at the level select screen, and you may use up to 3 at a time. Skills range from allowing you to pick up 3 ranged weapons instead of 1, to healing a single hit point, temporarily extending your attack range, freezing enemies, and more.

The time to complete level mode will vary by how much time you spend redoing a levels to get a perfect. If you simply try to beat all the levels, it should only take you about 6 hours.

That pretty much covers level mode, so let‚Äôs talk about survival mode. First of all, it‚Äôs important to note that survival mode is much different than the survival rounds you‚Äôll encounter in level mode. For that matter it‚Äôs also much better than level mode‚Äôs survival rounds. Before you begin an attempt at survival mode, you may select the skills you wish to use, and then you are thrown into combat. As you go along, enemy speed and difficulty will gradually increase. Every so often you‚Äôll be thrown into a weapon round (triggered by not missing and not being hit), alternating between light sword and nunchucks. They are not only a great way to quickly rack up extra kills, they also allow you to regain HP by killing a special enemy that charges at you every so often. Weapon rounds end after you are hit 4 times, and the hits you take during a weapon round do not detract from your HP.

Now let‚Äôs talk criticisms before we go. I mentioned two already, the horrid map design, and lack of an option to remap keys. Aside from that, the game‚Äôs menus and interface are clunky and more difficult to use than they should be. When you first launch the game it gives you the option to make the window size bigger or smaller, or to make it full screen, but you‚Äôre not able to adjust this once you make your choice without closing and relaunching the game. Thankfully, none of these criticisms detract much from the game.

When all is said and done though, OFDP is well worth a go, as stick figure combat is apparently highly entertaining. Plus it‚Äôs only a couple bucks, so why not give it a shot?

So you are a Stickman that is a master in Kung-Fu you are fighting against different enemies with their own skills. You can also pick up weapons from enemies or a Bow or Daggers. It's possible to unlock skills no sorry You MUST unlock skills^^ cause they make it all easier, not to easy but easier.

All in all it's a great fast paced indie game with very simple gameplay but very hard if you aren't reacting fast enough.

reviewText: Cheap, simple and hell of a lot of fun. If you're a fan of martial arts movies and good fight choreography and want something cheap and simple to pass the time, this game will do the trick wonderfully. Some of the moves and maneuvers you'll be pulling off just with two mouse buttons will give you plenty of 'oooooh' moments as well just laughing with glee as you take on hundreds of enemies like an unstoppable Jet Li. Doesn't hurt that they throw in a few twists to make things interesting including giving your a lightsaber or nunchuks and task you with deffeating over a hundred enemies before coming to a boss that has you feverishly matching the correct button presses to attack, counterattack, and dodge to defeat them.\n\nIf there's any downside it's that it gets pretty reflex intensive at times and requires you to get in a good rhythm for later stages and further in on survival mode. Otherwise, for $5, it's a great deal. If anything, the later challenge and zen-like requirement to pull the later action off might be a turn on for some people like myself. Making it perfect for killing anywhere to 10 minutes to a few hours of time.

reviewText:
Once you play it for 30 seconds, it's easy to see why it won awards.

This game captures what it truely means to be a gamer. Simple. Now go play it.

And fung fu master. The game mechanics seem so simple, however the Dev's have executed what is really one of the best experiences I have ever had in my 25 year long gaming 'career'.
It's a twitch shooter, a reflexive and strategic thinking machine (at the same time). It's timing, combos. You can pick up perks, there are about 7 different types of bad guys, lots of weapons, and a scaling difficulty level. With just two buttons.

But it's called 'One Finger Death Punch'!" I hear you say? I though the same

reviewText:
Do you like kung fu movies? Do you like indie games? Do you like 2D never-done-before type stuff? If you answered yes to any of these, I'd suggest picking up the game.
This quite the indie game treasure. Though it may look so simple by it's art style, the game play surely backs it up. It's a basis of you pressing two buttons as enemies aproach you while you kick their metaphorical and literal behinds. You may be thinking, Why can't I just walk to them and do that?" Then it'd just be silly. Clearly.

In this game

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game. It's absolutely balls to the wall action.

Warning though, if you are susceptable to Carpal Tunnel Syndrome or another mouse hand RSI then you probably should avoid this game for your health. You will be clicking a lot... like, A LOT A LOT.

After a longer session of this game my wrist definitely can get achy and hurt. It's made me realize that I need to get a mousepad with a wrist-rest on it.

It still stands though if you are a fan of cheesy action packed fighting then you definetly want to take a look at this game. It's basically every action scene of every kung fu movie ever made played together randomly shuffled forever, getting progressively faster until all the colors blur together the action is moving so fast and you are the protagonist in every single one.

So two words: Buy It...

unless your wrist breaks easily.

reviewText: This game looks simplistic and silly at first, but after playing it for a while I'm really impressed with how polished it actually is. reviewText:
After playing this game for the major part of an hour, I have discovered a certain amount of joy in its simple controls, fast-paced gameplay, and excellent visuals. You're thrown for a loop in early levels when enemies begin dodging your attacks. There are specialized weapon levels where you use weapons like nunchakus and light swords. Those are currently my favorite levels.

All in all, it's a fantastic first impression of a game and I can't wait to play more.

There's also a huge amount of achievements to get! So get to hunting!

reviewText: This game is pure brilliance. You will find yourself epicly mowing down crowds of enemies. However, there's a surprising amount of ways they can make the skills required for 2-button mashing different. You can have the bosses, where you go into each multiple hit part a bit blindly. Then there is the brawlers, which require fast thinking, planning, and reaction time. Then there is the normal part, which requires timing and speed.

reviewText: This game... :: Shakes his head. :: This game is..stoopidly ( Yes. I know I wrote it that way. ) addictive. It's simple as hell to play and it's mouth foamingly addictive. For the price and the enjoyment I got out of this game at $4.99. I bought three of these things and gave a copy to a friend and my wife. I haven't stopped clicking since. Well..except to y'know.. type this up. But... back to clicking the -‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•- outta these doods!! O____O!"

reviewText: This game seems so innocuous.  You could be forgiven for looking at the menus and simplistic graphics and thinking this is going to be something awful...but you'd be so, SO wrong. Buy. This.  Game.

reviewText: You've read the reviews about this game and they're all true.  This is essentially action games boiled down into a simple two button beat'em up; an on-rails brawler as the game says.  It borrows the old XiaoXiao stickman kung fu aesthetic from years past and turns the gameplay into a simple button slamming (but not mashing) experience.\n\nYou're in the middle of the screen - enemies at you from the left and right.  When they get within range"
date: your left mouse button/X button hits enemies on your left
recommended: and your right mouse button hits enemies on your right.  You'll kill them in one hit
hoursPlayed: but you'll do crazy looking moves to do so - stuff you'd see out of old 80s/90s kung fu films.\n\nSimple concept
voteText: right?  Most enemies go down in one hit and every hit you're rewarded with an awesome looking animation.\n\nBut it doesn't stop there.  The game takes this concept and runs as far and as fast as it can with it.  Later enemies will require multiple hits to kill.  Others require you to engage in a one on one fight in the middle of the level
helpfulPercent: and some enemies require you to hit them in a 2-4 button sequence of left and right presses.  Suddenly
votesHelpful: that simple "hit the button to kill an enemy" thing starts to get some bit of depth.\n\nThey add to this by letting you use weapons on your enemies: from bombs to bows
votesTotal: swords
votesFunny: spiked clubs
commentsCount: spears
column16: etc.  These weapons increase your range
column17: allowing you to hit the button earlier when an enemy is charging at you
column18: and you can even throw them at enemies if the conditions are right.  Some of them kill in one hit
column19: allowing you to take down those pesky multihit enemies that I described above.\n\nBut that's not all
column20: you can even unlock skills that allow you to initiate special attacks: do a screen clearing earthquake move
column23: and so on.\n\nCombine this simple yet incredibly deep gameplay with dozens of levels to play through
column27: and a parody of the traditional Chinese kung fu flick
column32: you can't go wrong.  And if you're reading this review during a Steam sale?  This game is a no brainer.  GET THIS.  You won't be sorry."

reviewText: This is a highly addictive, fast paced game. Not a button masher at all. Your moves need to be calculated and precicely timed. One Finger Death Punch punishes you for mistakes and makes combos rewarding. You can pick-up many weapons, both ranged and melee, which extend your reach when attacking oncoming enemies. With over 250 levels and multiple difficulties, as well as a three survival modes, there is plenty of challenge and replayability.

reviewText: A fighting game made in the most simplistic yet entertaining manner. The entire concept of the game is fighting by pressing two buttons. reviewText:
You might think this is the kind of game you will only spend five minutes on.
And you're mostly right, you'll spend five minutes on it... every day... for months...
This game is so easy to learn, but you'll be tearing your hair away in the grandmaster difficulty.
I don't know how it's possible, but this team managed to take a simple concept and make it an enjoyable mess of fun and violence.
The humor strikes true (No Luca, no!!) and for the price I had to pay this, it's more than a bargain!

reviewText: This game looks simplistic and silly at first, but after playing it for a while I'm really impressed with how polished it actually is. Controls and feedback are both super tight, and skill is a real factor. It's kind of like Super Hexagon except that you can't just memorize the patterns, which actually makes One Finger Death Punch the more interesting game in my opinion.\n\nPlus, when you beat the game, you get a video of one of the two devs congratulating you and saying thank you for playing indie games. What's not to love?

reviewText:
So I'll be honest,

I had some Steam Credit left over from the holidays and I decided to find the best reviewed games under $10 and I stumbled upon One Finger Death Punch - after looking at the reviews with over 99% approval rating I figured that I'd give the game a shot and for $2.49 if it didn't live up to the expectation it was less than coffee and a bagel.

Absolutely, by far worth the full price of $4.99 if not more. The game is addicting and it's enjoyable, playable for hours and an amazing form of stress relief.

If you don't have this game yet, you need to get it.

reviewText:
10/10

The most entertaining experience I've had in a long time. And that is not a statement I make easily.

With 14 game modes, and a good variety of weapons, enemies and power upgrades, this game just keeps on delivering punch after punch of glorious bone-shattering satisfaction directly to your teeth.

The pace is fast. And if it seems too easy for you, the game will simply adjust to a higher speed. And if it's still not fast enough, there are 2 more difficulties.

Visually, it's just pleasing to look at. Both from a player point of view, and as a spectator. With little fatalities" and interaction between player
recommended: the team at Silver Dollar have really squeezed a lot of juice out of a rather small lemon
hoursPlayed: and made one fantastic drink that I personally intend to enjoy in the shade all summer.\n\nMy one criticism would be
voteText: that I'm too slow for grand master mode."

reviewText: So simple, yet so enjoyable. You play as a ninja and your only keys are either left and right arrows or left and right mouse buttons. You fight enemies to move your ninja across the screen, and can pick up weapons and utilize them for quicker, more gruesome kills. Nothing is more satisfying than impaling a stick figure on a sword. For a game that you would think you would only play on a flash-games website at work or school, this has A+ gameplay. Sure, the controls, start-up, and main menu are simple, but simple is a lot better sometimes.

column16: pits you one on one in a time sensitive duel that requires the player to hit the right combination of left and rights when the correct indicator appears within an area of the screen designated the "Combat Zone".\n\nProgress through enough of the initial levels and you unlock the true gems of One Finger Death Punch. Survival mode is
column17: as you might expect

along with a vast array of weapons conveniently discarded by the piled up corpses of your foes.

But that's not all!

"Levels" mode also presents the opportunity to unlock a wide array of skills
column22: three of which can be active at any one time
column23: these range from additional ammo for ranged weapons (once grabbed from a dead enemy)
column24:
to bonuses to your standard attack range and even healing abilities that automatically activate after a set number of foes have been slain.

The skills you earn in "Levels" mode are directly transferrable to survival mode allowing a player to artifically postpone their inevitable death by swinging the balance of power slightly more in their favour.

Finally lightsabe... I mean "Light Swords" and Nunchaku. these particular level types appear both as singular set piece missions in the "Levels" mode and also as an additional saving grace in survival mode. In these modes the game shifts slightly in style
column25: the game world changes and the player and all his enemies become cast in shadow

column27: which lets face it is basically a green lightsaber
column28: at this point all enemies are one hit kill as the player effortlessly slices his prey into giblets. The Nunchaku is similar in it's styling however where the Light sword level appears to be quite hellish

column30: the Nunchaku round feels all "Cyber" casting the sky in digital blues and evoking feelings of Tron.\n\nThe Light Sword and Nunchaku play a more important role in Survival
column31: here they are represented on the screen by a slowly building bar which increases with every enemy you slay
column32: once the bar is fully built up by your kill count you enter the Light Sword or Nunchaku round
column33: now you have four energy orbs which replace your lives for the duration of the mode
column34: now you find that after roughly every 50ish black stickman minions you murder a single white minion will appear
column35: kill this guy and you gain a life back which adds to the amount you had remaining in the regular survival mode. Hits in Light sword and Nunchaku drain the four energy orbs you had meaning for as long as you can keep the Light Sword/ Nunchaku mode running you have the chance to fully replenish your lives to full so that once your last energy orb is gone and you return to the normal survival mode combat you have even more chance of getting a truly astronomical kill count.\n\nWith the game costing as little as it does there really is no reason why you shouldn't take the risk. reviewText: This is a game that takes old school Kung Fu movies and Rail shooters and makes a baby out of it. After playing it for some time I really want a new mouse when playing it. Presation wise its simple but this is not a game you should be taking too lightly. The game is a fast pasce fight which at first it holds your hand, but the game gets harder as you play on. I love the music which sets the setting petty well. There is no story as far as I know but they are penty of stages to beat through. One Finger Death Punch ain't for the weak of mind but its a game that I love to play for the kung fu than anything else. I'll give it a 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
One Finger Death Punch is an extraordinary game. It's combat is fluid and satisfying. Each hit feels like it's really making an impact. This is improved by it's very simple  Guitar Hero like combat. But be warned, this game doesn't allow you to button mash! The graphics in this game are simple, but effective! It shows each blow magnificently! People flying out of windows, being thrown at the screen... it's all cool!

reviewText: One Finger Death Punch is exactly the game to play when you don't feel like playing anything else. Even though playing with only the left and right mouse buttons, you quickly feel as if you're part of a kungfu movie yourself, putting Bruce Lee to shame with crazy martial arts. The better you play, the faster the enemies will move, and at certain points your reflexes are tested to their limits, as is your mouse hand.\nA perfect game for a rainy afternoon or just whenever. Still in doubt? Just get it!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Well, for the $2.49 I paid for it it's incredible. It teaches the basics well; it really is simply left and right clicking. I literally couldn't stop playing it the first time I launched it, managed to get 40+ achievements in a short period of time. It's so satisfying to see how perfect you can beat each level and each stick figure. There's fatalities, map destruction, explosions, decapitations, ribs breaking, hearts being punched out, throat punching, impaling, etc. You unlock different skills along the way such as receiving more ranged ammo, longer use of a weapon class(for ex. a staff or sword.) This bloody inhumane gameplay is filled with replayability and overall simplicity. I will forever enjoy killing everything in sight. Thanks for reading, and I hope you will consider purchasing this game >:D

reviewText:
Words cannot express adequately how much I love this game.
Perhaps 'Best Bruce Lee Simulator 2014'?
No, that doesn't cover a fraction of it.

Instead, let's go through a checklist:

- Intense gameplay with polished mechanics: check
- Skill and timing required to get perfect results: check
- Button mashing gets you killed: check, check, and check.
- Totally doesn't matter that the characters are stickmen: check
- Punch a man so hard his eyeball exits his skull: check
- Deathball juggling while the bodies hit the floor: check
- Punch a man's heart out of his body: check
- Slice a man's skull in two: check
- Nunchaku round; i.e 'I am ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Bruce Lee': check
- Light Sword 'totally not a lightsaber, but screw it I am the best kung fu jedi ever' round: check

Playing this game makes me feel like every character in every kung fu film ever.
I highly recommend it. It's a bargain even at full price.
